physDesc.p: Nine pages typewritten in black ink. Address given for H. D. in the top left corner of the first page: Mrs. Richard Aldington care of Mrs. Randall, 3 Christchurch Place Hampstead, London, N.W. England. Unsigned.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: Thank you a thousand times for your very nice letter of February 1st. I really was worried about you; I could not conceive where you were or what had happened to you, I had not heard for so long. I have already written to Richard and asked him if he knew whether you ever got "Can Grande’s Castle," as I felt quite sure that it must have gone astray with your various moves.

I am most sincerely grieved to hear of your brother’s death in France. What a terrible time this has been! I know how hard it must have been for you to be away from your family just now. Winifred Ellerman writes despairingly about passports, but I do not myself believe that there is any difficulty in getting them for any one situated as you have been, for I know my sister has just come home from England, where she has been for a year and a half staying with her daughter. An American wishing to return for a good reason can always get home. I think though, of course, that that would not apply to Winifred Ellerman.

Lawrence writes me that you are expecting another baby, which is good news indeed. I should think that you would be perfectly delighted. I do trust that all will go well, dear Hilda, and I only wish that Mrs. Russell and I could be there to do anything we could for you.

I am thankful that Winifred is proving stimulating and will induce you to write some more, for it is a wicked shame for you not to go on. My greatest satisfaction in regard to "Tendencies" is that it seems to have had the effect of bringing together various people who would not have known each other in any other way, and that is certainly a good thing.

You must be thankful to feel that Richard is out of danger. I am sure that ought to take a great load off your mind. I shall be extremely interested to see Mr. Shorter, but I do not know exactly when I shall go to England. My sister tells me, and Michael Sadler writes me, that it is too soon yet to think of making any impression with anything literary on the English public and that it would be better to wait for another summer. I am very anxious, if possible, to give some talks on poetry, as I have been doing here, when I get over, but I do not quite know how to go about that. At any rate, there is no use in thinking about it until demobilization is complete and things have settled down to a more or less normal condition. Also, my digestion is such a precarious thing that I cannot risk going over while there is any form of rationing still on.

I am sending you your and Richard’s draft for the half-yearly royalties of our anthology, and I am also taking the liberty of enclosing Flint’s, for I have no idea what his address is. Now, will you forward it to him and tell him that if he will send me his address I will write to him. The account is as follows: By Sales: 30 Imagist Poets, 1915 .36-1/4 10.88 17 " " 1916 .36-1/4 6.16 34 " " 1917 .36-1/4 13.32 10 do 1916 to Eng. 37-1/2 less 15% 3.64 10 do 1916 " " 37-1/2 less 15% 3.64 1/6 of 37.64 is $6.27 or 1.5 Flint’s draft is, therefore, £ 1.5.7 Yours and Richard’s £ 2.11.2

Lawrence writes in very low spirits. He keeps harping on the fact that he wants to come to America. I do not know whether America would suit him at all. They have certainly had a very hard time to go through, he and Frieda.

I have had a long letter from Richard apropos of this new translation series which he wishes to run, asking me if I will look after the American side of it. Of course I will do that or anything else which he wants, with pleasure, but as to making any translations myself, I hardly think that I will do that. There is so little time in the world, and I have not enough for my creative work. I cannot think that it is more important to translate than it is to write original things. Also I am embarked on a book of translations of Chinese poems with my friend Mrs. Francis Ayscough. You will probably have seen some of our efforts in the February "Poetry." I do not know when the book will come out, as it is a little difficult to work with anyone in China, but it is, perhaps, an advantage to me to have the originals of these poems come so slowly, because, by this process, I get them done without really realizing that I am giving any time to them.

Now here is something which I do not think that Richard realizes, and that is the entire difference in the market in England and America. Judging from the numbers of these translations which Richard wishes to issue, they are to be about the same little pamphlets about the same price that your last series was. Now I think it almost impossible to get anybody over here to handle such a series, the reason being that American booksellers want a large percentage for their trouble, and on a very low priced article, they cannot get a large percentage, and, therefore, they do not care at all about carrying such a thing. I know that was one of the difficulties, and always has been one of the difficulties, with our Anthologies. They were sold at seventy-five cents, and the booksellers’ commission was not enough to make it worth while for them to take much trouble. I feel sure that anything less than that in price would have no chance whatever. Also I do not think there is the same interest in translations that there is in England. A few of the poets, and a few scholarly people, might care for them, but I hardly think enough to make the project interest any publisher. However, I will try, and try my best, to get the things taken over here, and do everything I can, but I do think a great deal of water has run under the bridge since 1914, and I think that Richard would do better to concentrate on original work. It will not help us to be constantly booming poetry which is not our own. I do not mean for a moment that it would hurt us, and if we could make the translations and at the same time keep up our own output, that would be a different matter. That to me is an impossibility, although some other people may be more gifted in that line.

I do not think that Richard realizes at all what an enormous effect we have made in this country, and how different the situation is here from what it was four years ago. England is slower, of course, and England has been much harder hit by the war, but I think with proper management England can also be won. I seem to have developed a business talent, which I had never suspected, in getting people to take an interest in things which they never cared anything about before, and I cannot help feeling that if Richard would listen to my advice, we could really make a large impression.

I do not approve of doing things in an amateurish way any more. I think that puts us down as unsuccessful, and I think that Richard feels that too, since he wishes to have the new series taken up by a large firm. That, I think, is most important, and the most important thing of all is getting the original work put on the market properly. You know, in anything of this kind, one has to consider its effect on everything else one does. That is why I deprecated Richard’s selling his last book to Brown. It has not come out yet, and I do not know when it will. No amount of harrying Brown about it has any effect, and if Richard had made the changes then that he tells me he has now made for the English edition, I could have got it accepted by The Macmillan Company.

I may be unnecessarily dampening – of course, I do not know the condition of things in England – but, if I were Richard, I should certainly not want to give so much time to working with other people’s things. I should want to devote my time to working on my own, and I think he should get off "The Egoist" for good and all, for I do not believe in continuing to be tied up to a paper of that kind, a semi-amateurish thing, and one in which so many foolish things have appeared since Ezra put his finger in.

Richard writes and begs me to be broad-minded and not mind his asking Ezra to do some of the Spanish translations, even if I am associated with him nominally in the editorship, but I think that this would be exceedingly foolish, because none of Ezra’s things are translations at all; they are merely paraphrases. I can get you two excellent translators here. One is Mrs. Grace Hazard Conkling, an extremely good poet whose work you probably know, and who has done some vers libre things about Mexico that are most beautiful. She knows Spanish well enough to be teaching it at Smith College, and although she has, so far as I know, never been to Spain, she has lived for years in Mexico. I know that she has already agreed to do some translations for a little paper here which purported to have both Spanish and American poetry. The war has caused it to cease publication for the moment, but I know she was enrolled as one of its band of translators before it momentarily stopped. The other is Salamón de la Selva, a Nicaraguan by birth, and a man absolutely devoted to poetry. He has published a very nice little volume of his own in English, and he has also written a good many poems in Spanish, which is his native tongue. Lately he has devoted himself to translating Spanish poets for America and American poets for Spain. He has a large clientele among South American papers and is a very intelligent fellow and an exceedingly good translator. At the moment, he is in the Canadian army and has not yet come home, but I think he shortly will. Either of these people would be infinitely better than Ezra.

Now my feeling about Ezra is not in the least personal. I had as lief meet him as not, and I should be very glad indeed to have a nice pleasant talk with him, but I will not be associated with him in any literary enterprise, because I have discovered that to be known to be in collaboration with him at all is tantamount to writing one’s epitaph. The reputation which he once had has practically entirely gone, and it is absolutely suicidal to be associated with him in any public way.

I do wish that Richard could get a wider outlook on the literary world in general. You see, you and he do not see a great many people, and they are mostly in one set, as far as the poets are concerned, and that gives Richard a warped idea of the attitude of the world at large. I firmly believe that it is time for us to get out of a clique, to cease to act as though we were struggling for a hearing, and to take our places boldly as voices of the new day. I have at least achieved this magnificent summit here in America. I think, however, that I am anathema in Greenwich Village, for it is annoying when one is in an inlet one’s self to have any one else swim into the open sea. But for the past two years I have been trying to disengage myself from the amateur publishing ventures of the younger fry. I shall never desert certain old friends like "Poetry," but you remember that I decided not to publish in "Others" long ago, and "The Little Review" lost my valuable services when they tied up with Ezra. You see, I think there must come a time in the life of every serious artist when he ceases to be a beginner, and has a right to expect and claim proper recognition from the world he lives in. I cannot help thinking that one’s own attitude affects that recognition considerably. You know the old saying, that the world takes one at one’s own valuation. I think, if one constantly puts one’s self in the position of being, as it were, on the threshold rather than in the parlour of success, one is apt to be kept all one’s life kicking one’s feet on the mat.
I wish that Richard could write for some of the larger English papers. I think this could be done without any compromise whatever in his literary attitude; at least, I have found it possible here.

Richard wrote and asked me the other day if I could get him a regular letter in any of the papers and magazines, but that is, of course, difficult, as most of the papers already established have their own correspondents, and there are no new ones being started just now, and a good many, such as the "Seven Arts," had to stop on account of the war. I have written to Martyn Johnson about it, and he is enthusiastic, as always, about Richard’s work, but I do not know that he will take any definite steps in the matter. Of course, "The Dial" has a very small circulation, and it is devoting more and more space to socialism and politics generally, which is most unfortunate, but there are a great many other papers here for which Richard might write, I think; if he would send me some essays, I might try and place them in the "North American Review" or "The Bookman" or somewhere. You see, I did sell a poem of his to the "North American Review," last year, and then found that he had given it to that ridiculous little man in Cleveland, and, of course, it having been privately printed, the "North American" would not touch it. Richard’s attitude is very fine about giving all for art and not being paid for things, but really and truly, as a matter of fact, the world appreciates a good deal more a thing for which it has to pay than something which it gets for nothing, and it is the same with editors. I make a rule now not to give anything for nothing, except on the rarest occasions, and I have found this method to work very well.

Perhaps Richard’s tastes are too scholarly for the American public. The Letters he is writing to Greek Ladies in "The Dial" I feel quite sure would not appeal to any other paper, but there are plenty of things which he could write about, and which would be interesting to write about, that the more enterprising papers would be glad to print. I do think that the best thing possible would be for you and Richard to come over here sometime and see how things are for yourself, for I am firmly convinced that the market now will be America and not England. I do not want Richard to feel dampened in any way by all this, there is certainly not the slightest need of that, only I do want him to spend more time on completely original work and not spend so much time with the works of other authors, be they ancient Greeks or modern Frenchmen. His work is immensely liked, and he stands a chance of having a large and flourishing clientele. To my mind the only excuse for devoting so much time to translation would be that one needed the money and this was a way to get it. When that is not the case, I think it is really in almost every instance a waste of time. Certainly it is, unless it is kept very much at a minimum in proportion to one’s original work.

This is a long screed, but I thought that perhaps you could explain to Richard, a sort of supplement to what I am telling him, and as I said at the beginning, this does not mean that I will not do everything in my power to push the thing along, because of course I will.
Do write and tell me how you are when you get this. I am sorry to bother you with Flint’s draft, but I have no idea how to reach him otherwise.
